thread.title: First Alert Weather: Few light showers early, then warm and dry for Christmas week
thread.title_full: First Alert Weather: Few light showers early, then warm and dry for Christmas week

author: @WBRCnews
title: First Alert Weather: Few light showers early, then warm and dry for Christmas week
text:
BIRMINGHAM, Ala. ( WBRC ) - The forecast for tonight: High-pressure remains in control and moves southward. A surface front will enter into the state by your Sunday. It may spark a brief shower in the Mississippi Valley, possibly southwestern Alabama counties into Mobile Bay have higher chances. By Monday we dry-out and a ridge of high pressure will set-up shop over the Ohio Valley and shift into New England by Tuesday. That will increase our humidity and cloud cover on Tuesday afternoon. A back door front will move in by Wednesday and Thursday keeping us dry and high pressure will remain the main feature for the week. Highs will stay above average all week, topping out in the 70s. Merry Christmas.
Sunrise:6:48 AM Sunday, December 21, 2025 (CST) Birmingham, AL Sunset: 4:43 PM Sunday, December 21, 2025 (CST) Birmingham, AL Bluff Park Diner (WBRC) First Alert Weather Sky Vision (WBRC) The winter solstice marks the shortest day and longest night of the year. In the Northern Hemisphere, it occurs when the sun is directly over the Tropic of Capricorn, which is located at 23.5° south of the equator and runs through Australia, Chile, southern Brazil, and northern South Africa.The December Equinox in 2025, also known as the Winter Solstice, occurs on Sunday, December 21, 2025, marking the shortest day and longest night in the Northern Hemisphere, and the official start of winter for the year, with the opposite (longest day) for the Southern Hemisphere. It’s caused by the Earth’s axial tilt, with the North Pole at its furthest lean from the Sun.
Lake Tuscaloosa Pier 43 (WBRC) Young Jewelers Downtown Jasper (WBRC) Key Details for 2025:
Date: December 21, 2025. Significance: The Sun reaches its lowest point in the sky in the Northern Hemisphere. Northern Hemisphere: Marks the start of winter, shortest day, longest night. Southern Hemisphere: Marks the start of summer, longest day, shortest night. What to Expect: Daylight: You’ll experience the least amount of daylight for the year. Night Sky: The Ursid meteor shower peaks around this time, offering some celestial viewing opportunities. Saturday high pressure extending from the Tennessee and Ohio Valley is down through the Louisiana coastline, then high-pressure shifts to the Mid Atlantic coast Sunday high pressure extends from the Big Bend region of Florida to Nantucket on the East Coast Sunday the tail end of a clipper system in Alberta clipper, mixed with Upper level Troughing and An area of low pressure that develops along the Texas coastline by by Monday Tuesday-Friday: high pressure remains the dominant feature through the week Cullman - WKUL (WBRC) First Alert Weather Sky Vision (WBRC) Submit your weather photos, videos Get news alerts in the Apple App Store and Google Play Store or subscribe to our email newsletter here .
